name: Whizz
description: Whizz is one of the few 3D platformers to use an isometric viewpoint. The controls reflect this, with moving the controller to the right actually moving the character down and right, moving it down and right moving the character down directly, and so on. Each level is played out against a time limit, and the paths through the level aren’t always clear-cut. There are four different types of doors, each of which needs a particular icon to pass (the icons represent the door type, such as ice or bricks, rather than hot water or a key, or anything you’d logically expect to clear the path). You can avoid the baddies, which may be the best option, as killing them costs you some energy –this reduces the significance of the points system.
alsoFor: DOS, PlayStation, SEGA Saturn, SNES | Combined View

shot.caption: Having found myself unable to get far (or even not that far...) in the DOS version, I turned to the Amiga version with cheats...
Winter world with cozy little huts.
The goal of each level: find the final section (marked with a chessboard pattern, like the start) and leave with a balloon.
Whizz uses a lot of different means of locomotion in various levels: sleds...
...or even a dart (no, this is not a broomstick).
In beach levels, springboards look like those inflatable rubber castles on beaches and funfairs.
Beach screens! Which disproves the popular Polish "autoracist" theory that only Polish people are so distrustful and hostile towards everyone else to use screens on beaches.
A component of chance: use the slot machine and you may win coins which will form a path (but just not necessarily in the first attempt).
